review_title: Better than other HEI in the sector but similar issues remain here too
job_title: Professional Services Manager in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: * Friendly colleagues who make day to day job worthwhile; * Salary in line with sector expectations; * Good induction and thorough training at the start; * Was proactive during the pandemic and put good plans in place that recognised the difficulties staff were facing; * A can do attitude in some areas of the institution
cons: * Good policies in place but not always followed through on - more surveillance on these are bedded down would be better; * Difficult progression for those in professional services, hard to move through the role, no clear path compared to academic / researchers career path; * Job creep and taking on more tasks than in job description, usually covered in the contract with the get out of 'tasks reasonably required to fulfill the role' * Hiring managers do not get enough equalities, diversity and inclusion training to hire; * Pretty obvious who the senior / exec management 'favourites' are that keep getting promoted, it leads to a one sided view which, if you don't agree with, can leave you out in the cold; * Need to engage with Unions such as UCU on pensions, precarious contracts, zero hours contracts and workload management - this is rife across the sector, Strathclyde is better than most but that isn't saying much, is still a problem management could deal with

pros: Strong industry links. Strong in engineering.
cons: Terrible leadership, just awful. Really intelligent people, but a very careless attitude towards doctoral research. I've been lied to about resource availability, I've been paired with professors who have no expertise in the field they are supervising, I've had to figuratively twist the arm of professors and budget holders alike just to get support to obtain the necessary materials for experiments. Don't do your doctorate here. There is a high turnover of students and an even worse record of them being able to finish at all. See reasons above.

pros: Great group of colleagues. HR, IT, technicians etc. were all fantastic. Good laboratory resources. Overall, a collegial environment. Most people saw others as co-workers and friends.
cons: Terrible management. During the pandemic, only people with permanent contracts got promotions. The rest of us trying to get up the ladder were told to burn the candle at both ends because we were not yet "competitive enough". However, we were never told what it was we were lacking to become competitive. Unless you already had support from some big wig, management considered you as insignificant. When management felt generous enough to give career advice, it become clear that they are from another era and completely out of touch with current trends (e.g., the importance of visibility via social media), often giving you bad advice. In summary, don't expect to progress if someone important is not funding/backing you.

pros: a great all round university

pros:
It is a nice place to work if you find the right group. 
The support staff is really nice and helpful.
Some very good science is done.
Despite what most of the people say Glasgow is a nice place to live (if you avoid the east end).
The beautiful sceneries of Scotland are just outside your door.
cons:
Some groups can get overwhelmed with PhD students and the more senior staff swamped with work trying to help them get data. 
Some of the senior people in the physics department look like they haven't been out of their lab in ages, which is a bit depressing. The physics dept lack a feeling of community, people tend to have limited interactions apart from when work is involved.
The facilities are quite old, buildings build in the 70's and full of asbestos. But apparently there are plans to build new buildings and knocked down the old ones in a couples of years.
The weather can be horrendous, but you would expect that in Scotland.

pros: Home to some motivated and extremely inspiring supervisors. Fantastic opportunities for research - however, very difficult to carry it through without funding, which is not easy to go by.
cons: Simple tasks such a booking rooms for research and teaching purposes are extremely difficult and very poorly coordinated. Considering the wealth of campuses and the amount of admin teams at Strathclyde, this should not be the case. This also applies to financial management - recurrent mistakes in processing pay claims, and a finance team who are very dismissive of your issues, with little interest in resolution.  Furthermore, casual work is very poorly coordinated and the rate of pay is hardly desirable. Wouldn’t be the first time I’ve showed up for some work and it’s been given to another colleague.

pros:
Best HEI I have worked for (I have worked for 4 in total) and Strathclyde is without a doubt the only place that I have ever felt proud to work and I plan on staying long term. 

Supportive and collegiate environment with the right level of responsibility/ autonomy - this place is worlds apart from another Scottish HEI I worked where there was a lot of bullying and harassment. No problems like that at Strathclyde. 

The Uni Executive team at Strathclyde really seem to put its staff wellbeing first and have a clear sense of direction. The University rewards its staff for hard work with additional annual leave when it receives national HEI awards etc. Pay is better here than some other HEIs.
cons: None that I can’t think of. My personal experience has been great so far, I hope other people have the same experiences.

review_title: University of Strathclyde as a PhD student employer
pros: Good environment overall. The university or the societies that belong to it or the SIPBS institute are interested in making the adaptation easy and provide a good international exchange between students at a social and professional/ research level. Stipends and demonstration salaries always payed on time.
cons: The registration process to the university can be quite bureaucratic making the start for students at times difficult. The university has several departments and the SIPBS itself has a lot of administrators and dealing with all those people and knowing who to go to to take care of a problem can be at times tricky.

review_title: Good place to work in for a while
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
- Friendly environment
- Great city with a lot to do in!
- Some good facilities 
- Excellent continuous professional development (CPD) programmes
cons:
- They DO NOT promote their own; they are always seeking "outside" talent. 
- Funding is the main focus, not research quality. 
- Due to money being the main concern, they are mostly interested in people with industry connections, but will not help you acquire any. 
- Dropping in worldwide rankings.
- Non-existent work-life balance

pros: Working as a researcher is exciting and rewarding. I really recommend the university of strathclyde if you want to undertake an academic career.
cons: Managing your research career can be exciting, challenging, rewarding and frustrating all at the same time and at any stage! It can be demanding, especially if you are an early career researcher.

review_title: Strathclyde Business School is an excellent employer
pros:
Depts strive for equality.
Supportive of new ideas.
Lots of natural light for offices.
One of the best IT and Staff I've ever worked with.
cons:
Security never seems to figure out who should be allowed in the building.
Grading methods are too subjective, confuses our students.
Treat PGR candidates as if they're migratory birds.

pros: Great place to work, the staff are all very positive and friendly and the job is good fun. For any student I highly recommend trying to get this job and running campus tours ect it's ideal to work around classes.
cons: There aren't really any downsides except sometimes not being able to work as many hours as you'd want to. Sometimes you need to work outside in the cold or the rain which I guess is a con.

pros: Highly research oriented, Well equipped and forward thinking place of learning. Location couldn't be better. Entrepreneurial University of the year 2013. Students from every department are trained to be entrepreneurs here
cons: Not very international, expensive tuition words, it is hard to meet people because the university is so big.

review_title: Great place to do a PhD
pros: I undertook a PhD within the Chemical Engineering department and the support they offer is excellent. I knew I could go to my supervisor with any problems whether they were academic or otherwise.
cons: The only downside is that the building is not well ventilated and the rooms are either stuffy or freezing.

review_title: Great colleagues and opportunities for learning & development
pros:
A lot of interesting colleagues, who work had but also know how to have fun!
Great initiatives to commercialise research, a lot of help with finding funding. 
Good links to industry
cons: As all Universities things move a bit slowly, but I guess that's their nature!

review_title: Pretty good. Challenging and motivational environment with access to the pharmaceutical industry

cons: Shared office spaces with other departments, noise levels could be high during working hours. Still academic environment so slow paced.

review_title: Very good place where grow and become a leader

1. Very welcoming environment
2. Technical staff always ready to help
3. Very good research facilities
cons: The only downside is the lack of investment in post-doc position from the University. Without a proper research funding, only PhD position and lectureship are funded by the University.

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: Excellent place for biological research, staff really helpful and friendly even though I was on a short-term contract.  Tried to help me out as much as possible when diffculties arose which meant I would have to leave.  Quite a sociable bunch too!
cons: Suffers a bit being in the shadow of University of Glasgow and not having a medical school

pros: Completed a PhD there and the majority of the staff members are friendly. There are a vast range of projects, depending on your interests.
cons: The groups are very competitive and there are a lot of jealousy between groups.

review_title: Very good place to work and live.
pros: No politics, plenty of space to develop personal ideas. Helpful colleagues and a general sense of working in the company of highly knowledgeable staff.
